div.head:
Embleme 13. Of the Secrets of Nature.
The Philosophers brasse is hydropicallhydropical, and desires to be seven
times washdwashed in a river, as Naaman the leper in jordan.

lg.l: Infesting, has noe cure but one alas:
Naaman the leper did himselfe restore,
Bathing his limbs in Jordan o'reover and o'reover;
Soe if your brasse be washdwashed in water pure,
Its præsent, Hydropsy will not endure.

div.head: Discourse 13.
div.ab:
That Naaman the Syrian betookebetook himselfe to Judea as the perswasionpersuasion of the
Prophet, and washdwashed himselfe seven times in the river Jordan, is to be ascribdascribed
to his confidence in the Prophets words, but that hee was freed from the Le
prosy by that washing, is a miracle of divine omnipotence: For the Leprosy,
which being seated in the blood, and radicall parts of mans body, is as it were
an universall Canker, cannot be cured or taken away by any externall-
washings, much lesse of cold water, such as was of Jordan. After the same-
manner that the Philosophers brasse diseased with an Hydropsy, Should be
freed from it by the washings of water, yea that being imperfect it Should be
reduced to perfection, and being sicke to health, soe as to be able to coḿunicatecommunicate
the same to other sicke bodyes, is next to a miracle: For such an example is
not elswhere extant in nature, nor is it the ordinary way of nature to pro
duce the Philosophers most absolute tincture, unlesse it be governed by art,-
and fittfit subjects administredadministered to it with the externall efficient. Soe the resti
tution of luxations or dislocations is not peculiar to nature, but art: Neverthe
lesse the Os Sacrum opens itselfe miraculously in the birth of a child, that-
the infant may thereby have egresseegress, as by a door, and herein the most great
and mercifullmerciful God operates by nature above nature: Soe that the Stone-
should be perfected, may seemeseem to be a thing supernaturallsupernatural, though really
it is naturall: Wherefore sayth a Philosopher in the Rosary, You must know-
that our stone is airy and volatile, externally cold and moist, internally-
hott and dry: and that coldnesse and moisture which is externall, is a watrywatery
fume, corrupting, blacking, and destroying itselfe and all things, and flyesflies
from fire: and that heat and siccity which is internall, is gold hott and dry,
and is a most pure oyle, penetrating bodyes, and is not fugitive, because the
heat and siccity of Alchymy tingethtinges, and nothing els: Cause therefore the
externall, coldnesse and watry moisture, to be like to the internall heat and
siccity, soe that they may agree and be united together, and all at once be
made one penetrating, tinging, and fixing body: but these moistures must be
destroyddestroyed by fire, and degrees of fire with soft temperament, and a congruous
and moderate digestion: These there: But if true, how can it be freed from-
water by water? but it may be answered, that some certaine waters are-
hott and dry in quality, such as are many baths, in which it must be Phi
losophically washed: For this is that which they say, wash with fire, and-
burne with water; for that fire, which washethwashes, and that water, which bur
nethburns, differ one from the other in name onely, but agree in effect and ope
ration: That brasse therefore must be washdwashed, that is, dryed from its super
fluous moistures by this water, or this fire: Wee have knowne experiments-
of HydropicallHydropical bodyes cured by six monethsmonths absence from any drinkedrink,-
by being buryedburied in hott sand, or CowesCows dung, by being put in a hott fur
nace, and sweating, and innumerable other helps, yea allso by drying-
baths, such as are at Carolina and Wisbadenses not farre from Mentz:
By the same wayesways must this Patient be cured, sometimes by waters,-
Discourse 13.
sometimes by the hott aire of furnaces, sometimes by dung, sometimes Sand,
and by abstaining from drinke: for these are most effectualleffectual remedyes in both
cases, here and there to be used: but in all these things heat is the operator,-
which drawesdraws forth and consumes the superfluous water by the EmunctoryesEmunctories
or allso pores of the body: For externall heat quickens the internall, that is,
the vitall Spirits, to expellexpel that moisture which is noxious to it, as an unpro
fitable excrement, by which the naturall heat was before suppressdsuppressed as by-
an enemy: In this cure there is need of great diligence and præcaution,-
lest whilst one bowell is helpdhelped, another be hurt: In a Quartan (the Plato
mickePlatonic probation of a Physician) wee find, that thicke and viscous humors,
like the gummegum or glewglue of trees, being gathered together from all the veins-
and massemass of blood, doe descend through the hollow or great veins even to the
bottomebottom of the backe, where obstructing the emulgent veins, which draw
the serous humor out of the blood, or the passages of them, they are lesse-
able to operate, and more serous liquor remainesremains in the body, and soe in
a short time, if care be not taken, a Dropsy may happen, the other bowells
being allso untainted at first: DiureticksDiuretics doe here little or noe good, purgatives
yet lesse, unlesse diminution and eduction be made in some certaine series of-
time: SudorificksSudorifics are allso manifestly hurtfullhurtful, because they draw out the more-
subtillsubtle parts, leaving the thicker, and being continued debilitate the body: for-
the custome of nature is to find that way to evacuate serosityesserosities through the pores
when shee is obstructed about the bladder: This therefore is Scylla, the other-
Charybdis, both which hee that has a mind to præserve himselfe ought to-
avoyd: But that Dropsy which proceeds from an impaired Liver or Spleen,-
if it be confirmed, is of most difficult cure: Now in the Philosophicall-
brasse the cure is not impossible, the distemper being rather by accident,-
and secundary, than essentiall or primary, provided it be cautiously be
gun, as wee have sayd concerning the plenty of serum in a Quartan, to-
witt, that it may not by overmuch exiccation fall into a consumption, or
by humectation into a Dropsy difficult to be cured. . . . . .
